poem:
**Resurrection on Spike Island**

Once sidelined shadows in Britpop's glare,  
Pulp ascends the stage anew, unsure—  
a ghostly groove finds footing in forgotten beats.  
Jarvis, sartorial specter, questions return  
yet crafts crescendos from awkward awe—  
an island echoes their once-shelved song,  
a second coming of harmonious haunt,  
where past doubts dance into the present's embrace.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Pulp: Spike Island review – Jarvis Cocker and co’s joyous second coming It seems weirdly fitting that Pulp have premiered their first album in 24 years with a song that appears to fret about the validity of returning at all. Of all the alt-rock artists hoisted to mainstream fame in the Britpop era, they were the ones who seemed least comfortable with the kind of attention it brought them: a perennially ignored band who’d spent". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
